awd_titl_txt: Frameworks for Generic Robust Inference, Mismeasured Spatial and Network Data, and Nonlinear Dimension Reduction
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will conduct three sub-projects to improve upon existing statistical inference methods. There is a need for more generally applicable easy-to-use simulation-based statistical inference methods that exploit the availability of machine learning and other advanced data processing techniques. This project will develop more broadly applicable simulation-based inference methods. It will enable measurement-error robust inference in models based on spatial or network data. Finally, the project will improve the scalability of nonlinear dimension-reduction techniques. The simulation-based statistical inference methods developed under this project will have significant impact on data science in general. Research efforts increasingly rely on sophisticated data analysis methods where traditional simulation methods fail to provide reliable inference. Studies in the social, medical, and natural sciences increasingly are leveraging the broad availability of spatial or network data as well as high-dimensional data. These fields will be significantly impacted by the methods to be developed. Graduate students will play an important role in the development and implementation of the proposed methods.

This project will push the boundary of existing inferential methods via the use of a broad range of novel concepts. The investigator will use the idea of super-sampling, in which an augmented sample, larger than the dataset itself, is generated and optimized to represent the true population. The research will exploit the idea of using neighboring data points in spatial or network data to disentangle the true signal from noise. The project extends that domain of applicability of existing resampling methods that are based on the observed sample or subsets to carefully constructed hypothetical populations larger than the sample. The project also will address the presence of measurement error in spatial or network contexts by viewing neighboring data points as repeated measurements of the true underlying variables of interest. These measurements do not conform to classical frameworks based on statistically independent errors and thus demand dedicated techniques. Finally, the nonlinear dimension-reduction techniques to be used will merge the concepts of optimal transport, entropy maximization, and simulation-based estimation in novel ways. Dimension reduction techniques have applications in fields as diverse as finance, psychology, neurology, data compression, information retrieval and processing, and machine learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Unobserved (or “latent”) variables are very common in the social sciences, where variables such as skills or preferences, which are very hard to measure accurately, play an important role in modeling human behavior. This project leverages the fact that modern datasets often contain a large number of imperfect measurements (or indicators) of the underlying unobserved true variables of interest. As a result, it becomes possible to disentangle the noise from the common signal present in these redundant observations.

This project has considerably furthered the set of tools available to researchers to perform robust statistical analysis in these general high-dimensional settings with latent variables. The broad classes of models covered by this project include: (i) spatial or network models, where the underlying latent properties of a given sampling unit can be inferred from the knowledge of its related neighboring datapoints; (ii) nonlinear factor models (also known as dimension reduction techniques), where one seeks to identify a low-dimensional latent model from the knowledge of a high-dimensional vector of observables; (iii) measurement error-type models where a latent variable model is identified from the knowledge of the full distribution of low-dimensional set of variables; (iv) generalized method of moment estimators, in which a high-dimensional set of moment constraints (i.e., averages of nonlinear functions of the data) are used to identify a parameter of interest. The techniques used to achieve the above include machine learning, optimal transport, nonparametric and sieve methods and lie at the forefront of statistics and econometrics research.

Broader Impacts

Linear dimension reduction techniques have found applications fields as diverse as finance, psychology, neurology, data compression, information retrieval and processing or machine learning. Thus, extensions of these techniques to nonlinear settings, are likely to enjoy a similarly broad impact.

As specific products, the project has produced a comprehensive review of the field as well as a paper describing a completely new nonlinear dimension reduction technique, both published in top broad audience journals (the Journal of Economic Literature and the Journal of the American Statistical Association, respectively). Other products include three publications in top field journals and three more currently in the publication pipeline, one of which is at the “revise and resubmit” stage at Econometrica, one of the leading economics journals.

The project is also making computer codes implementing the proposed methods available, either as supplementary material to publications or distributed as a Stata implementation.

The applications employed to demonstrate the usefulness of the methods have important implications for the social sciences in general. For instance, our approaches were used to confirm an apparent relationship between pre-colonial political structures in Africa and present-day economic prosperity. They were also used to confirm the existence of causal relationship between preexisting transportation networks and economic development as well as between life expectancy and economic growth across countries.

 


Last Modified: 10/20/2024
Modified by: Susanne Schennach
